The problem isn't that sexualized characters exist.

The problem is that characters who are women are far more likely to be sexualized than men--independent of whether it makes sense for that character or in the world those characters live, and the way those characters are sexualized often appeals to only a very specific type of man. 

For example, there isn't a single black woman in League of Legends, and there are only two black men. That means only about 1.4% of League's champions are black. Whilst the US is obviously not the only country to play League of Legends, it is one of the largest, and Riot Games was founded there. Approximately 13% of the US population is black.  We'd expect there to be closer to 17 black champions if we used US demographics. 

As a living breathing gay man...I promise you that there're almost no men in League of Legends who are sexualized. Buff men are power fantasies for men. They aren't 'eye candy' for women or men who are attracted to men. If I so much as mention the fact that I have a boyfriend, I'm 'shoving my sexuality down others' throats'...meanwhile I get to listen to inane comments about Sona's or Ahri's breasts constantly.

Some of us aren't straight white abled cisgendered men. We want to have characters that appeal to us.

 That's why things are changing.

And why they will continue to change.

Those papers are even peer reviewed and harshly scrutinized..and then refined! Just like every other academic profession.

I literally just provided you an actual statistic (which is easily verifiable) regarding black representation in League of Legends.

Here's another one: There's exactly one champion who is confirmed gay out of the 141 champions in LoL. Two if we count Taric, where a developer mused in a Q&A that he probably wouldn't care about gender. That's .7% if we just count Varus, and 1.4% if we count Taric. Either way, the LGBT population in the US varies state to state, but is between 2-8%.

These ideas aren't anything radical and aren't being pulled out of nowhere. You're the one making bold and unqualified claims.

As far as I know, Taliyah is confirmed as bisexual.
Vi is heavily hinted as bisexual as well.

And there is one important thing missing in this argument: you let it seem like all these champions not directly confirmed as homosexual or bisexual would be heterosexual....
But they aren't.

In fact, there are not so many champions with directly confirmed sexuality, simply because it never mattered in their lore until this point.

That may be the case for Taliyah. I am pretty slow to work through the newer lore, and I certainly don't see the posts of every developer. Vi may also count as bisexually coded, but it could still easily be argued that she is not. Either way, that is still very different from an explicit confirmation.

And yes, you're correct. We do make the assumption that most characters are straight until told otherwise. There's good reasons for doing so. Have you ever heard the phrase 'the exception that proves the rule'?

For example consider this: 'Olaf removes all disables from himself and becomes immune to them for the next 6 seconds.'

We can glean, with no other knowledge, that champions are not typically immune to disables. Why? Because if they were, that information would be redundant.

This is just about your own expectations, tho.
You are the one assuming that a champion is heterosexual, just because it isn't proven otherwise. And Riot simply doesn't have to confirm a sexuality if it's not important for the story of the champion.

Varus' sexuality matters, because he is 3 beings fused together, 2 of them being lovers.
But how does the sexuality of Jinx, for example, matter? Until now, knowing that Jinx is lesbian would change absolutely nothing.

At this point it is just like in real life. I meet plenty of people and I already automatically assume that someone is bisexual until proven otherwise. There are many people I meet in university and I have no clue about their personal sexual preferences, because they simply don't matter in the context I am working with them and people don't always smack you in the face what they are digging.
